I did't describe the  MXNET_GPU_WORKER_NTHREADS problem clearly. The network has 3 lstm layers, the seq_len is 16, some operators in different layers can be parallelized in theory. Just as the following pic shows, operators in the same back-diagonal can be executed in parallel. I think MxNet's engine can handle this case.
![image06](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18651286/15462803/aa6ec5f8-20f7-11e6-8211-7898a346fc38.png)

# Discussion

This is an interesting topic to discuss, and related to what @mavenlin and I discussed a while ago. Think about efficiency in executions, there are three causes:
- The memory latency and total save load cost of kernel
- The cost of kernel launching between consecutive kernel calls
- The cost of the kernel itself.

Currently mxnet parallelizes the workload within single card, which meas it can likely hide the kernel launching problem by a bit. But in our experience, it is likely to be around 25% gain. There are several potential cause here:
- The scheduler is not yet very optimized so there is still gap between kernel launching(likely to see gaps between kernel executions)
- The kernel is optimized for quickly execution and occupy all resources, but when there are small kernels, they still occupy all resources to prevent other workload to occupy GPU
- The fused kernel reduces memory fetchs and increases speed overall

# Directions

Only the last direction will involve a NTC or specially optimized code. But I do think there might still be something to gain by simply sharing workloads and possibly using customized kernels that aimed to take partial resources. It is very interesting to see if it is possible to do so without loss of flexiblity.

Basically we are using `grad_scale` in optimizer to do this function, so I think in this view it won't be fixed.

I assume mxnet uses cross entropy as the loss function of softmax, so mathematically its gradient should be divided by n. You can see https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/regression_output-inl.h#L76, where the gradient is also divided by num_ouptut.

Thank you again for contribution! I will add a normalization Parma today,
which will also consider ignore label case. I am worried current change
will break many example and old code.

@tqchen A simple idea comes to my mind is to restrict the resources used by small kernels, such as reducing the block numbers and block size, increasing the computations of each thread.
@mli The hardware I use is M40. I see no difference in speed when I changes the value of MXNET_GPU_WORKER_NTHREADS from 1 to 3

From the profiling result that @feiyulv showed, the small kernels are executed sequentially because the MXNET_GPU_WORKER_NTHREADS is set to 1. It could be helpful to also see the same graph when this value is set to 3. 

I think the following parts are optimizable.

## Multistream execution

The current engine would not determine which stream to use based on the dependency. The streams are used in a pulling way, whichever finishes first will pull the next kernel for execution. Therefore it is not guaranteed that the red blocks would be in different streams. But the work load would be balanced in this way.

In the multiple branch case, the efficiency of the engine can be further improved when the streams are used based on the dependency. For example, kernel that depends on other kernels should be scheduled to any of the streams of its depending kernels. A stream can be dynamically allocated(or get from the pool) when there is a bifurcation, and send back to the pool for reuse when the bifurcation merges back. 

As @tqchen mentioned, whether paralleling with stream is beneficial is also decided by the resources that the kernel uses. In most of the cases, there is space for improvement because the resources are not used up. In the case each kernel is optimized to use all the resources it might even hamper the performance (but also depends on how well NV people have optimized the context switching of streams).

## Gap between Kernel Launch

From the profiling result, I believe this is the major cause of the bad performance. Because the gaps are as long as if not longer than the kernels. This is caused by the current scheduling method of the engine. Although cuda provides an asynchronous interface, current engine is not using it. Instead, after a kernel is launched the engine will immediately call cudaStreamSynchronize. It is until the current kernel is finished, the callback function will launch the next one.

> User -(async)-> Engine -(sync)-> Cuda

## Prescheduling the kernels

Combining the above two points, a prescheduling engine can be developed.
- By prescheduling, the gap between kernel launches can be hidden because engine to cuda is now async.

> User -(async)-> Engine -(async)-> Cuda
- This is also beneficial for embeded torch module (or other functions in script but calls cuda), because as long as the last step is async, we can preserve the performance.

> User -(async)-> Engine -(sync)-> Lua -(async)-> Cuda
- Streams are balanced when they actively **pulls** from a task queue, it is hard to achieve this balance when we do prescheduling which means **pushing**. It is then necessary to schedule the kernels based on the dependencies.

> Instead, after a kernel is launched the engine will immediately call cudaStreamSynchronize

This is a major issue for small kernels. We should fix this. @tqchen Can you work on a new engine?

Hi @YuetianLiu 
Please refer to my tutorial
https://github.com/haria/mxnet-multi-task-example/blob/master/multi-task.ipynb

actually, I modified data iterator as below.

``` python
class Multi_mnist_iterator(mx.io.DataIter):
    '''multi label mnist iterator'''

    def __init__(self, data_iter):
        super(Multi_mnist_iterator, self).__init__()
        self.data_iter = data_iter
        self.batch_size = self.data_iter.batch_size

    @property
    def provide_data(self):
        return self.data_iter.provide_data

    @property
    def provide_label(self):
        provide_label = self.data_iter.provide_label[0]
        # Different labels should be used here for actual application
        return [('softmax1_label', provide_label[1]), \
                ('softmax2_label', provide_label[1])]

    def hard_reset(self):
        self.data_iter.hard_reset()

    def reset(self):
        self.data_iter.reset()

    def next(self):
        batch = self.data_iter.next()
        label = batch.label[0] # the original label here
        label2 = mx.nd.array(label.asnumpy()>5).astype('float32') # new label based on the original label, output 0 or 1 here
        return mx.io.DataBatch(data=batch.data, label=[label, label2], \
                pad=batch.pad, index=batch.index)
```

Good Luck!

Seems like the k-max pooling (http://arxiv.org/pdf/1404.2188v1.pdf). I think you need to create a new k-max-pooling Op. Refer to the examples in http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/how_to/new_op.html, http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/system/operator_util.html and also source code https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/src/operator.

I figured out that the direct reason is because in lstm_unroll function, 

```
label = mx.sym.transpose(data=label)
label = mx.sym.Reshape(data=label, target_shape=(0,))
sm = mx.sym.SoftmaxOutput(data=pred, label=label, name='softmax')
```

the label is processed as the code above, which makes mxnet graph engine think the label variable becomes an input variable.
I tried to add a fake 'softmax_label' variable to provide_data, which pass the infer_shape function, but still results in another error,

> ```

> 
> ValueError: need at least one array to concatenate

the output_list is empty which should contains the softmax_label as output.
Not knowing how to make it work.

@gleery Which `lstm_unroll` are you using? Yes there is a potential issue, if you are using [the one in ptb rnn example](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/rnn/lstm.py#L48), because that example applied transformation to the labels. So you will need to provide (fake) label shapes to make it work. This is inconvenient, we will need to refactor it, but if you want to know, [the lstm_unroll in speech demo](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/speech-demo/lstm_proj.py#L53) solved the problem. 

For the error in `prediction`, if you are using bucketing, make sure to set `merge_batches=False` when calling prediction. Because if different batches are of different shape, then it is impossible to merge them. Please see [the doc](http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/packages/python/module.html#mxnet.module.base_module.BaseModule.predict) for more details.
it seems a debug print, should be removed
I am adding get CPU resource function. The purpose is to make behavior uniform to other toolkit and make it easier to reproduce result.

this is because mxnet runs asynchronizely, and update_metrics is the only point where the process block and wait for the prediction. So the time spent on update_metrics contains the time needed for forward operations, as well as previous backward updates
the iterators you are combining has different number of entries per epoch. i.e. when one iter has finished the other is still going. They need to have the same length

`ADD_LDFLAGS = '-L/usr/local/opt/openblas/lib'`
and
`ADD_CFLAGS = '-I/usr/local/opt/openblas/include'`
in the `config.mk` file should work for you.
python package does support fp16. julia package doesn't

normally it should check if the array is initialized. We should fix this.
Maybe just disallow empty arrays
numpy seems to treat empty array as scalars
This can hurt performance. Ideally you should do what you want with the output before calling forward on the next batch

@piiswrong Thanks for the reply. Actually the image data, labels and weights contain 60000 entries (or rows). And for both the iters, I set the batch size as the same. So I don't think it's due to the different length issue. But after debugging, I found that in my customized iterator, when `iters[0]` (i.e., `ImageRecordIter` for images and labels) becomes `None`, `iters[1]` (i.e., `CSVIter` for weights) is not. This looks quite strange to me, since the batch sizes are the same for the `ImageRecordIter` and `CSVIter` in my code and also they both have 60000 entries for the MNIST training data.

@piiswrong @tqchen Thanks for your replies. i tried both your suggestions and the issue remains. I found that if I use another gpu with 6 GB memory, there is no out of memory because the maximum gpu memory usage is about 4.2 GB, which is sufficient for this card but not for my previous one. What is interesting is that why it takes so much memory to reshape if the new executor shares the memory with the old one? 
If I change the shape to a fixed one instead of random one like this:

```
temp_shape = (1,3, 700,700)
```

there is no problem, even without wait_to_read or copyto. The memory usage is only 180 MB. I guess there should be some extra memory usage during the allocation of the new shaped arguments, but 180 MB compared with 4.2 GB seems a little big difference. 
This only happens when I frequently change the input size. Any help would be really appreciated.
try to avoid allow_up_sizing and always allocate the largest executor
